data.title: TypeScript extract function/method
data.body:
new refactoring options (extract method & function) are not available unless you use VSCode's TypeScript version.  when i use my workspace's version of TypeScript (2.3.3) the refactoring options are missing.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 x64
- OS Version: Windows 7

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Error span causes refactoring suggestions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (b0c0634339c6f64a5c7f08b56fe732fb9154d3c4, 2017-09-15T05:24:23.107Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
**TypeScript Version:**  nightly (2.6.0-dev.20170915)
---

Moving from Microsoft/TypeScript#18507 as this looks like a vscode issue.

**Code**

```ts
function f(): number {
    return {
        x: 1,
    }
}
```

The entire `return` statement has a red squiggly line under it.
Click anywhere in the error span and there will be a suggestion to refactor to an inner function.
Remove `: number` and there are no refactoring suggestions.
(Tested in vscode.)

**Expected behavior:**

Presence of a compile error doesn't cause a refactoring to be suggested.
Especially because it looks exactly like a code fix, but extracting to an inner function won't fix the compile error.

**Actual behavior:**

It does.
In fact, hovering over the light bulb shows "Show Fixes", but this is a refactoring, not a fix.

data.title: Feature request: add time stamp to edited/newly created comment
data.body:
e.g.
```javascript
// 9/15/2017@10:53am Some comment that was true at the time
/ *
* 9/15/2017@10:53am Some comment that was true at the time
* /
```
Change any of the text in the comment and the time changes.

data.title: Ability (api or command) to paste into the terminal
data.body:
I've been thinking about some possible new features in GitLens now that there is a repository visualization. Like more advanced commands, rebasing, etc. And while some of them could be just fine to run on their own, others might require more terminal interaction or something like that.

So I was thinking if there was a way to paste commands into the terminal (NOT run them), it could help some of those scenarios, and/or help people learn the command line commands of certain operations easier -- which could be valuable outside git or anything like that.

data.title: VSCode not responding when I change 4k files at once in the workspace.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 64bits

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have VSCode open with a workspace loaded
2. Run a script (from outside VSCode) that writes 4000 files very quickly
3. The window hangs out and finally asks me to "reopen" it.

Reproduces without extensions: No.

Here are my extensions :

```christian-kohler.npm-intellisense
dbaeumer.vscode-eslint
dzannotti.vscode-babel-coloring
eg2.vscode-npm-script
EQuimper.react-native-react-redux
fknop.vscode-npm
joelday.docthis
msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome
robertohuertasm.vscode-icons
Shan.code-settings-sync
shinnn.stylelint
slevesque.vscode-hexdump
steoates.autoimport
timothymclane.react-redux-es6-snippets
xabikos.ReactSnippets```

data.title: Editor ruler is offset by 1 column
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
markdown-preview-github-styles|bie|0.0.3
python|don|0.7.0
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.5.1
php-pack|fel|1.0.1
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-scss|mrm|0.6.2
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable `editor.ruler` in the setting.
2. Place your cursor at the ruler.
3. Check the line/column information in the bottom right corner.

Example: When setting `editor.ruler` to 80 the information displays col: 81 after placing your cursor at the ruler in the editor. It is basically offset by 1.

I have the feeling that the ruler should be at line 80 and not line 81, since the description of the setting also says:  "Columns at which to show vertical rulers".

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Multiple item selection in explorer
data.body: For deleting and reorganizing it would be nice to be able to select multiple files/directories in the explorer by holding down a modifier key while selecting.

data.title: Auto-bullet

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature request: when I am writing a bulleted list (e.g. in Markdown or plain text) and hit enter I would like the editor to continue the line prefix.

Example:

* bullet 1
* bullet 2
[hit enter]
* [new line has bullet/spaces mimicking lines above]

Another key feature is if you hit enter on an otherwise unused bullet it will get out of list mode. I think you could do this as an extension, as well, but I haven't found one that does this.

data.title: Window crash after exec two internal powershell terminals
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Insider Preview 1703 (16281.1000

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open one terminal and exec gulp (gulp watch)
2.Open other terminal and exec sass 
3.Vscode crash
(Maybe not crash inmediatly)
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**/No

data.title: Stale launch configuration read by extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Any

In our extension we have an action which generates launch.json file. We just use fs.writeFile and place the proper content there.
Up until vscode 1.16 if you press F5 after launch.json has been generated, it will pick it up and execute whatever is specified there.
Starting from version 1.16 VsCode "does not see" launch.json the first time you press F5 and only succeeds the next time.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone the extension https://github.com/dennisfrostlander/vscode-launch-bug
2. npm install
3. Open the project and run extension with F5.
4. In the extension host, open an empty folder.
5. Run the command "Hello world". It will generate valid launch.json. Inspect the file to make sure it's there.
6. In the extension host, press F5. VSCode will show debugger selection list although the launch.json exists.
7. Press cancel and F5 again, this time VSCode will attempt to start a debugger.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: window.activeTextEditor.viewColumn is undefined for diff editors
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a diff editor (from git) in the second or third view column
2. trigger the editor title action "Open File"
3. :bug: the file opens in the first view column

I think the Git extension [is doing the right thing](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/commands.ts#L368) for this command by setting the view column to be the one of the active editor, which in this case is the diff editor. However, it looks like the view column is always `undefined` for diff editors at least. 

Tracing this down the stack, it looks like [`MainThreadDocumentsAndEditors#_onDelta`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/api/electron-browser/mainThreadDocumentsAndEditors.ts#L274) is called with the left hand side of the diff editor as well as the right hand side (both instance of `CodeEditor`). As such, the method [`_findEditorPosition`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/api/electron-browser/mainThreadDocumentsAndEditors.ts#L357) will not function properly because it [compares](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/api/electron-browser/mainThreadEditor.ts#L318) the `CodeEditor` to the `DiffEditorWidget` which is opened.

data.title: highlight more than 999 items using CMD+F2 does not work.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (128a4e3640c5375f7b0bc1cfd37f626481b1386f, 2017-09-12T05:10:59.101Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

I cant highlight/edit more than 999 items when using CMD+F2.

1. command+f2 try to select highlight item which has more than 999 identical items in the same file.

data.title: Shortcuts ctrl+left and ctrl+right don't move cursor to expected positions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Win10 x64

1. I want to move cursor between words using ctrl+left and ctrl+right
2. In most editors, and in Visual Studio too, cursor would move to the left or right and position itself before the previous/next word's first character.
3. But in VSCode it does not work that way - it moves to first/last character of the same word.

Very frustrating as it's not the same as in VS or the 99% of IDEs and editors out there. Even here in GitHub it works that way, try it for yourself.

data.title: Shortcut ctrl+del doesn't delete trailing space
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Win10 x64

1. I want to edit "foo bar baz" to "foo baz"
2. In most editors, and in Visual Studio too, I would position cursor before "bar", and press ctrl+del, which would delete "bar" as well as the space after it.
3. But in VSCode it deletes "bar" only, and leaves the space, which I must then delete as well.

Very frustrating as it's not the same as in VS or the 99% of IDEs and editors out there. Even here in GitHub it works that way, try it for yourself.
